messages.text: After a class, the students sprint out shouting with joy because finally they have PE. Everybody except Peter. Peter excels in maths, likes to play the piano, but he has never liked PE. He* is overweight and this is something that has always gnawed at him, especially in the changing room, where he* has to change in front of his schoolmates. He* almost always gets insulting comments. And today, it is no different.
C‚Äômon, Peter, go cover up that big belly, please. Nobody wants to look at it.
The entire room bursts into laughter.
You really need to lose some weight, Peter. Or no girl will ever want you. Well, maybe Andreja, 'cause she's fat, too.
Everybody laughs, and Peter looks away with shame.

The boys* change into their sports clothes and go to the gym. The teacher says they should run five laps of the gym. Peter runs on his own, because he runs slower. Every time Anja overtakes him, she* screams into his ear:
Fatty, you're so slow. Will you even be able to run whole five laps today?

The teacher does not comment on the situation. Peter is also quiet. In his mind he* is mulling over whether he's really too fat. He* thinks that his schoolmates must be right and it is his own fault for being overweight.
WHAT DO YOU DO?

üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è You say to Peter that he* can run with you and you start talking to him: ‚ÄúDon't listen to them. They should be the ones embarrassed because they are so narrow-minded, not you. People are much more than just their bodies. Regardless of how you look you have lots of talents, like, being good at maths and playing the piano. You should be proud of yourself. Look, if something similar happens again, tell me and we'll solve it together.'

üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è You add fuel to the fire by saying, ‚ÄúDamn Peter, you still haven't gone to the gym?‚Äù You don't think you said anything wrong, because every guy should take care of his body and be physically strong to be attractive to women. Maybe this will finally encourage him to take better care of his body.
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èYou ignore the situation and mind your own business.
‚ú® EXPLANATION ‚ú®

Usually, body image is considered something that only concerns women*. Research shows that exposure to images of ideal female bodies negatively influences girls*' image and self-confidence. But there is less research on how ideal images of tall, muscular and athletic male bodies influence the self-image of boys* and men*.

An article in Men's Health magazine about the confidence of men* in relation to social media showed that every third man* feels the pressure of having to look good on social media. Almost one half of the participants felt the pressure to Photoshop their photos to help themselves look better. Almost a half of them made several selfies to obtain the right one. 
With the occurrence of social networks and influencers, bodies, commonly only belonging to professional athletes, suddenly seem easily achievable also for an average man*, if you attend a gym, drink protein drinks and are on a diet. Anorexia and bulimia are no longer just a problem for girls*, but also for boys*.

So not cool! üò§ It‚Äôs a fact that we all have different body figures and that any figure is completely ok. Think twice before you criticise others because of their body, because sometimes words hurt more than blows.
Your response is music to our ears! It is so good to hear that you are ready to selflessly stand up for somebody else. üí™ If only there were more people like you.
Just as you throw your notebook on the table to finish your maths homework, your phone starts vibrating. You look on the phone and see Miha's text:
Mate, got a sec, can I come to your place? I‚Äôve got to tell you something.
You think to yourself, ‚ÄúEven when I am trying to do the homework I can't seem to be able to finish it.‚Äù You text him back, ‚ÄúYeah, sure, no problem, come round.‚Äù

Within 15 minutes Miha is standing in front of your door. You both go to your room and sit either side of the bed. You notice that Miha seems to need to get something off his chest and he is nervously biting his nails. ‚ÄúWhat's up?‚Äù You ask.

Oh, everything, really. I broke up with Julia two weeks ago and I'm so down. Every now and then I totally panic, because I think I missed a chance, and I am also afraid that she'll tell others that I suck. I don't know how to even process what‚Äôs going on in my head.

I swear it's been so difficult to even go to school lately, because I know I'll see her. I tried to speak about it at home but they don't get it. Mum said I should stop fooling around and start studying. And dad didn't even want to listen, he just said I should stop crying, that a man shouldn't cry over a woman.
You noticed too that lately Miha has been much more reserved and withdrawn.
WHAT DO YOU DO?

ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 'Ah, c'mon mate, pull yourself together! I'm just here trying to do my homework for tomorrow, and you come around annoying me with this stuff. Your father's right. You shouldn't be sad over a girl. Find another one and you'll feel better.'
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è You quickly say that it will pass and try to distract him by starting to talk about a football game that is on TV tomorrow.

üß° 'Why didn't you tell me before? It isn't easy for anyone to split up with someone they really like. I think you just need some time to process everything that has happened. And if you still feel bad about it, just text me. You can always rely on me, especially when you‚Äôre really upset.‚Äù
‚ú® EXPLANATION ‚ú®

The depression rate in men* is estimated at 8 % (in women* it is at 12 %). However, it is also less likely that men* will seek professional help or access mental health services. It is also reported that men* have significantly reduced access to support through friends, relatives and the local community. An average of three out of four suicides (76 %) are committed by men*. 
Research shows that boys* and young men* learn early on to avoid seeking help when problems arise, because speaking about anxiety or pain is often understood to be a sign of weakness.

Come on, what kind of friend are you anyway! üò† Clearly Miha really struggled with finding someone to talk to about his distress. You should feel honoured that he confided in you with all of this! If you show that you care for your friend or that you struggle with some situations you are no less a man* for it than if you conceal your feelings.
Ok, where can we apply for your friend‚Äôs list üòâ! It's very honourable that you helped Miha in his distress and saved him from more distress by saying that he should not be sad.
You and your three best friends decide to go to a club to make good use of your last summer weekend before school starts. The moment you get to the club, Jure notices a nice girl* on the dancefloor.
Damn, she‚Äôs so fit! You go get the drinks, and I'll go into action. I'll give you a sign about how it goes.

You separate and go towards the bar. You order drinks for the four of you and wait for the signal from Jure. You can see him making his way through the crowd and slowly move towards the girl*. She* dances with two other girls* and you see that they have noticed Jure coming closer. They try to move away, but Jure catches up. He approaches the girl* and says to her:
Hey, what's the hurry? I cannot let such a hottie escape me.
Jure holds the girl* by her shoulder. *girls* laugh with unease*
Hi, I'm Jure. Do you think that being such the beauty you are you would give me your number?
The girl* feels she has no other choice but to give him her number. She does not want to make a scene. Jure goes on boisterously:
Let me get you some drinks.
He signals you to bring three more drinks for the girls* and you join them.

You join them on the dance floor and you start dancing together. You enjoy the dance, but you see how Jure persists in hitting on the girl*. He steps behind her and grabs her bum and holds her by her hips to dance with her. The girl* tries to wiggle away from him and is visibly uncomfortable. Her friends tell him to leave her alone, but Jure pushes them away and says he does not want anything bad, plus he bought them drinks.
WHAT DO YOU DO?

üëç You encourage him for sure! The girl* is really hot and Jure has to take the chance to get laid before school starts again. The girl* is just a little shy that's all, she'll relax and then she'll want it.

üí¨ You pull Jure away from the girl*, although at the beginning he resists, you insist. You invite him out for a smoke, where you say to him: 'I totally get that you like the girl*, but you gotta take it easy man. Don't force yourself on her if you see she is not into you.
üìû You ignore the situation and look at your phone.
‚ú® EXPLANATION ‚ú®

Patriarchal society teaches men* about two patriarchal norms regarding having sex with a woman*. The first is that sex is transactional ‚Äì it can be attained through buying it (for example, a man* that buys a drink for a woman* on a date can expect sex from her*). And the second is that sex is negotiable ‚Äì it is possible to negotiate about sex; this means that 'no' does not mean 'no'. Rather 'no' means that you have to put more effort into trying to make her* say 'yes'. Both of these assumptions or norms are wrong.
Therefore, it is important to underscore that consent means the presence of 'yes' rather than the absence of 'no'. This means that if somebody does not say 'no', this does not mean they have said 'yes'.

Oh my, oh my! üôà If the girl* says no, that does not mean that YOU can keep on bothering her! Only SHE* can decide whether she wants your attention or not üêì. If you're not sure if she* wants to talk to you or not, ask your mate who responded to the situation with the last answer to advise you.üëå
You are the type of friend everyone wishes they had! You deserve an A+. üíØ

With a few of your buddies from the Discord you decide to play Fortnite again after a long time. You are super excited because you have been trying to do this for some time, but never seemed to find the time that would work for everyone. After you finish the first game, another player joins your team going by the name of @maja006. This causes astonishment in the group and you ask in the chat whether she is maybe a girl*. Maja replies with a short, ‚ÄúYup.‚Äù
Nik opens up a debate:
Ugh, a girl won't know how to play, why did we get her on the team? I bet we're gonna lose just because of her.
For real, I don't know since when girls also play videogames. This world is so messed up. Once it was clearly defined that women took care of the family and children. It's all mixed up now.

Yeah, that's exactly why I listen to Andrew Tate, 'cause he actually tells it how it is. All that he says I think in my head, but I don't dare to say it out loud, because I know girls would get at me straight away. In one podcast he says it well that if you tell the truth, such as, that women are more emotional and men are more rational, people immediately say you're sexist.

The boys* get so absorbed in the conversation, that they forget they are still playing. They win the round, but most of the credit goes to Maja because she succeeds in finishing off the largest number of opponents.
I'm a hundred percent sure she got help from a guy. It's impossible for a girl to be so good at Fortnite. Why are you so quiet?
WHAT DO YOU DO?

üéÆ ‚ÄúBoys, I think we have to admit that Maja was the best in this round. I was also sceptical at the beginning, but I'm really surprised about how skilled she is. I mean the girl* really nailed it and I don't know why we should take the credit away from her just because she's a girl*.‚Äù

üëç You wince, because you were absorbed in the conversation. ‚ÄúYeah, I mean, I totally agree with everything that has been said. It's obvious the world has gone mad if we have to accept that it's normal for women* to play Fortnite.'
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚ÄúSo ... yall want to play another one?‚Äù You don‚Äôt wish to get involved in the conversation.
‚ú® EXPLANATION ‚ú®

Misogyny is widespread online for several reasons including anonymity, online communities, and lack of control. Anonymity enables people to express hostile opinions without fearing the consequences, and online forums encourage hate speech among the equal minded. The lack of control of online platforms enables the unpunished spread of misogyny.

Men* who are taught to be strong and independent can struggle to express their vulnerability and emotions, which can lead to hostility toward those who are more open in expressing their emotions, which often includes women*.

It's good that you answered like this so we can teach you something new üòâ. Society gives us thousands of instructions on how to behave. But at the same time, we forget that society is all of us. Me, your schoolmate, us. We can all do something to change the outdated patterns that are harmful to us.
Way to go! üëè It takes lots of effort to expose yourself like this in front of a groups of friends.

On the school radio the principal summons the students to the gym to watch a presentation of a dance school. When you come to the gym it is already bursting at the seams with practically the whole school gathered there. The dance teachers start their presentation, when in the crowd they suddenly see your schoolmate ≈Ωan who also dances at their school. They call him up on stage because they think it would be cool to hear about his experience with their dance school. ≈Ωan is a straight A-student, but he is quite reserved and quiet. He* hesitantly comes up on stage, where the dance teachers ask him what type of dance he* is doing at their school.
Um, I do hip-hop ‚Ä¶ um‚Ä¶ in the junior group. Um‚Ä¶ and, yeah ‚Ä¶ this year I also started to dance in the male solo category.
*silence*
The silence that follows ≈Ωan's comment is broken by Jakob who shouts scornfully across the entire gym.
He isn't even a boy, but a girl! Just look at him! He‚Äôs totally gay!

The entire gym bursts into raucous laughter. The dance teachers look at each other and try to calm the situation down, but without any success. ≈Ωan returns to his place staring down at the floor, ashamed.
WHAT DO YOU DO?

üó£Ô∏è You think to yourself, ‚ÄúJakob is right. He does look more like a girl than a guy. Guys don't attend dance schools.‚Äù You shout towards ≈Ωan, ‚ÄúHaha, it‚Äôs true. How will you dance in the male category, if you look like a girl! You‚Äôre such a queer!‚Äù

üï∫ You clearly stand up for ≈Ωan, because you think the comment was totally out of place. You shout loudly to Jakob, ‚ÄúHey, stop it!' You approach ≈Ωan on your way back from the gym and ask him* to wait for you in front of the school. You tell him* you think it is awesome that he* is interested in dance, because you know about many successful dancers from all around the world and you believe he can make it if that is his wish. You tell him* that if something similar happens to him* again he should come to you and you will do something about it.
ü§£ You laugh along with the others, although you don't find Jakob's comment appropriate.
‚ú® EXPLANATION ‚ú®

In patriarchal ideology homosexuality represents everything that is symbolically excluded from being a 'real man'. 
The achievement of 'real' masculinity is a process in which men* supress a series of emotions, needs and possibilities, such as susceptibility, sensitivity and empathy, because the sexual norm connects these to femininity and softness, which are supposedly incompatible with masculinity and power.

No one can ever completely fulfil the norms of 'real man', which demand power, invulnerability, and independence, because men* also have emotions, needs and insecurities. This triggers a fear in men* that their peers could identify them as too feminine, i.e. emotional and vulnerable, and label them as gay. 
The word ‚Äúqueer‚Äù has nothing to do with homosexuality, instead it is an expression of an ultimate contempt for all men* that appear too feminine, powerless or are not 'cool' enough.

No one deserves to be insulted like that in front of others, regardless of the type of insult. If you dance that does not automatically mean you are gay. And even if he* was gay, so what? Sexual orientation is your own personal thing. Every individual deserves respect and equality regardless of their sexual orientation. It is better for you to show support to the target of the insults rather than joining the insulting or being quiet. This requires a lot of courage, because by exposing yourself you risk becoming a target of scorn yourself.

What an absolute legend! ü§ô You could not have reacted in any better way in this situation. First, you immediately stood up for ≈Ωan, clearly showing that Jakob's comment was completely out of line. Then, you showed him support by telling him* it was okay for him* to dance and that he* should not worry about what others think.

At the end of break you catch a piece of a conversation between your classmates about the Barbie movie. The boys* claim it is only propaganda for women* wanting to fill their brains with modern feminist messages. The girls* defend themselves and say boys* don‚Äôt understand because you have to be a woman* to understand a woman*'s experiences, which is the main theme of the film.

At that moment the school bell rings and the sociology teacher comes in. Despite the loud ringing the conversation continues. The teacher listens to the students for a few minutes to catch the subject of such a heated debate. When she* finally silences the class, she* takes the opportunity to talk about the content of the film, the position of women* in society and the importance of feminism.
Miha, who was the loudest in the debate, speaks up first:

I think that male feminists don't exist. We really no longer need feminism, because women are now equal to men. Now the feminists just want to push out men and it‚Äôs no longer about equality, because women today are already stronger.

Yeah! I don't know where women are still not equal to men. They have practically everything. They can work and earn their own money, on dates they are the ones who pick us and not the opposite, we only pay. To be honest they even have too many rights.

You're out of your mind! Feminism is not only about women being subordinated, it is about equality in general. And yeah, there are still cases where women are not equal to men. Say, at the same job women often earn less than men, or they are still expected to take care of the home and the children, just because they're women.
The teacher turns to you and asks you what you think.

üëé ‚ÄúIt really sucks that we have to pretend that we care about feminism. If we say anything against women, even if it is a fact, then we are immediately labelled as sexists. And I also don't want to see the movie, because it's a load of rubbish.‚Äù
ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è You say you do not know and you do not have an opinion about it.
‚ùó ‚ÄúMen still have absolute predominance in today's society, but they don't recognise it, because they have many privileges that they do not want to give up.‚Äù
‚ú® EXPLANATION ‚ú®

Feminism is often wrongly presented as an anti-male ideology, as a movement that strives to get rid of men*, because men* are supposedly the main problem in society. But this is not true. Feminism is a social movement critical of the imbalance of power between women* and men*, and it strives for equality, regardless of gender.

Even if many men* are aware of sexual stereotypes and unjust gender norms, because they can see them in their everyday lives, they still consider feminism unhelpful in the modern world, because women* now have the right to vote, they have jobs, and are no longer only ‚Äì housewives. 
If a man* defines himself as a feminist, often other men* consider him weird, unmanly or a traitor. Some men* (and some women*) think that men* who define themselves as feminists try to attract women* by pretending they care.

Andrew Tate would definitely be proud of you if he had heard you üòí. We do not judge, because the opinion that we do not need feminism is still (too) common, even among women*. But let us make one thing clear. Feminism is not against men*, but encourages both men* and women* to rid outdated stereotypes that do not contribute to a more solidary and just society, in which we want to live.
That‚Äôs how it‚Äôs done! We know your mum would be so proud of you. üòá

#split
point < 6 = "nasilna mo≈°kost"
point < 12 & point > 5 = "soudele≈æena mo≈°kost"
point > 11 = "nenasilna mo≈°kost"

Based on your answers it seems that you tend to be overburdened with sexual stereotypes and with how a 'real man' should react. Maybe you follow Andrew Tate too much (or associate with someone who does)? üòâ Even if you show your emotions to others, feel powerless, help those who are weaker and have friends among women* and gay people, you will not be considered less cool. Many people would say that this is when you become a 'real man'.

Woohoo! üéâ Based on your answers it seems that you tend to prefer to follow the crowd and those in power, but at least you don't encourage violence. Perhaps occasionally you are even prepared to stand up against violence. We know it is difficult, because we all grew up with images of violent masculinity, which is why it seems normal to us. And this is why changes towards non-violence and equality can be so demanding. You need a lot of awareness and much courage for such a change. Just keep going, you are on the right track!üí™

The only fight you involve in is the fight for non-violent masculinity! With your answers you managed to achieve the best possible result. Congrats! ü•á Your answers imply that you are successfully overcoming sexual stereotypes and practice non-violent masculinity. Your answers show that you respect differences between people, that you are able to empathise with others, and are prepared to help those close to you. You really understand that we all have to actively strive against the promotion of harmful stereotypes, hostility, violence and injustice so that they do not stop us fighting for solidarity, equality and justice. Share your knowledge with others, because you can be a role model for many. Keep it up! üôåüëë
